node.text: Rachel Gurjar (@rachelgurjar) is showing us her take on a classic gin and tonic with @bombaysapphireus, taking inspiration from her Indian heritage. With curry leaves, mango, and lime juice, this tangy and super refreshing cocktail feels like summer in a glass. #StirCreativity

node.title: 99 Gin and Tonics: Curry Leaf and Mango G&T

node.text: Al Thompson (@drunkenmixologist) shares his version of a gin and tonic with @bombaysapphireus. With the combination of bright, citrusy grapefruit and floral lavender, this G&T becomes the perfect rooftop cocktail. Simple. Refreshing. Delicious. #StirCreativity

node.text: Watch as @eatwithchrissy makes a tangy, slightly spicy margarita using @cointreau_us, Scotch bonnet peppers, grapefruit, lime, and blanco tequila. This riff on The Original Margarita uses Scotch Bonnet peppers to give a satisfying kick.

node.title: Margarita Season: Scotch Bonnet and Grapefruit Margarita

node.text: Watch as @andybaraghani makes a sweet and refreshing margarita using @cointreau_us, muddled pineapple and mint, and lime, and blanco tequila. This riff on The Original Margarita is quite possibly *the* drink of summer.

node.title: Margarita Season: Crushed Pineapple and Mint Margarita

node.text: Melissa Miranda (@meltronica) shares her version of a gin and tonic with @bombaysapphireus, taking inspiration from the Philippines with a riff on the Gin Pom. With grapefruit, ginger, cardamom bitters, a squeeze of lime, and @bombaysapphireus, this drink will remind you of being on the beach. #StirCreativity

node.title: 99 Gin and Tonics: Ginger Grapefruit G&T

node.text: Julie Reiner (@mixtressnyc) is showing us how to make her spin on a gin and tonic with @bombaysapphireus. Julie grew up in Hawai'i and uses that for her inspiration, with watermelon, lemon, and coconut water for a bright burst of summer. #StirCreativity

node.title: 99 Gin and Tonics: Watermelon Coconut G&T

node.text:
**Sound On** In honor of Mother’s Day, best-selling author and poet Kwame Alexander (@kwamealexander) asked 12 accomplished writers to reflect on how their lives—and their kitchens—mirror their mothers. Everyone got the same prompt, “I am becoming my mother,” and this community poem is a result. Head to the link in our bio to read more about the authors.
Contributors: @vanggarrett, Lesléa Newman, @engle.margarita, @marjorythw, Richard Michelson, Janet Wong, @georgiaheard1, @amstephens_, Maritza Rivera, Reuben Jackson, Lorna Goodison, @erikalsanchez, Deanna Nikaido, and Kwame Alexander

node.title: Kwame Alexander Reads The Ceremony of Giving

node.text: Watch as @empschultz makes a salty blueberry and ginger Margarita using @cointreau_us, muddled blueberry, ginger simple syrup, and blanco tequila. This riff on The Original Margarita was inspired by a blueberry, ginger, and orange pie she made last summer.

node.title: Margarita Season: Salty Blueberry & Ginger Margarita

node.text: DeVonn Francis (@tuna__turner) is showing us how to make his unique take on a gin and tonic with @bombaysapphireus. DeVonn uses pineapple as a nod to his Caribbean roots, celery to compliment the herbaceous notes in the gin, and bay leaf to tie all the ingredients in his Pineapple Celery G&T.

node.title: 99 Gin and Tonics: Pineapple Celery G&T

node.text: As a kid, Brooklyn artist Kemar Wynter (@cowfootsoup) would rush home from school to help his aunt peel carrots, stir pots, and marinate meats. What began as a childhood obligation morphed into a lifelong passion. With titles like ‘Macaroni Pie,’ ‘Auntie Del’s Stew Peas,’ and ‘Aunt Pearline’s Potato Salad,’ Wynter’s jubilant and motion-filled abstract paintings honor the dishes and chefs he holds dear. “I think it’s important to [preserve] that notion of lineage,” Wynter told contributor Julie Poole. “I was the first person in my family who was born in the U.S. So I see myself as a record keeper and I think of my practice largely as a form of archiving—both of my family’s recipes and the stories attached to them.” Click the link in our bio to read about how Wynter’s work has evolved over the pandemic, the importance of upholding history, and his favorite vegan cookie in the city. 📷: @isa.zapata

node.text: When Kevin Wilson (@crossculturechristian) posted his first chai-making video on TikTok, he had no idea it'd go viral. The Sri Lankan-born, California-based pastor and teacher had joined the social media platform only to experiment with it... and maybe to see what his students were up to. But today, Wilson's videos—a blend of soothing, ASMR-adjacent tea tutorials and frank discussions about topics like the BLM movement and Asian American xenophobia—garner views in the millions. "I used to think my story was a liability because I had low self-esteem," he says now. "The fact that I have an accent, look the way I do, or don’t fit into groups was working against me. I wanted to run back home. But I realize now that your story is not a liability. It’s your greatest superpower." Here's a glimpse of Wilson doing his thing; click the link in our bio for more. 📷: @ampayaban

node.text: We've never met a potato we didn't like—but we still have our favorites. We asked  @moroccochris @samanthaseneviratne @susanhjkim @brad_leone @rawlstonwilliams and @chefharoldvillarosa to share theirs. Watch the full video on YouTube at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on August 30, 2021. May be an image of food.

node.text: If you’re looking for a vegetarian main to serve at your next dinner party, look no further than this harissa-roasted eggplant dish topped with crispy capers. Think of capers as plant-based anchovies—they’re salty with a unique acidity, and are the secret weapon in this recipe from assistant food editor Jessie YuChen (@thelescook). Capers infiltrate EVERY layer of this dish. They’re chopped and mixed into a spicy harissa rub for the eggplant, mixed with cherry preserves for a salty-meets-sweet dressing, and roasted for a crispy-crunchy topping that adds pops of flavor. Click the link in our bio for the recipe. 📷: @emmafishman 🍴: @rebeccajurkevich 🥣: @sophiestrangio

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on August 29, 2021. May be an image of dessert.

node.text: Freeze-dried strawberries are our new baking obsession. You’ll understand why once you’ve made this recipe for Strawberry Doughnut Muffins by senior cooking editor Sarah Jampel (@sarahjampel). Sweet, juicy fresh strawberries are a gift, but when we want to get super-concentrated strawberry flavor into cookies, cakes, and more, we reach for freeze-dried berries. They’re consistent in flavor, texture, and sweetness, and can easily be worked into these tender muffins without fundamentally altering their structure. Click the link in our bio to make these jam-filled treats. 📷: @emmafishman, 🍴: @rebeccajurkevich 🥣: @sophiestrangio

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on August 28, 2021. May be an image of drink.

node.text: This grape-tarragon spritzer with frozen grapes (!!) is the perfect refresher for your late summer cookouts and garden parties. The idea came about after chef Bryant Terry (@bryantterry) used frozen grapes to cool down some sparkling water after running out of ice. The anise-like flavor of the tarragon syrup goes well with the sweet, refreshing grape juice. “Topping off the concentrate with sparkling water and adding frozen grapes makes it a modern, fun treat,” Terry says. (And we won’t tell if you add a little gin or vodka as well.) Click the link in our bio for the recipe. 📷: Oriana Koren 🍴: @mrsmochi 🥣: @jjoules

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by bonappetitmag on August 27, 2021 tagging @lindasivrican, and @sesame.la. May be an image of 1 person, standing and indoor.

node.text: When perfumer Linda Sivrican (@lindasivrican) found the sunny little storefront on N. Hill Street in L.A.’s Chinatown, she imagined it as a temporary site from which to launch a fragrance collaboration with a local chef. But then she expanded her vision. “I thought, Let me do something fun that the community could really embrace,” Sivrican says. “That’s why I turned it into a market.” Now @sesame.la is a neighborhood superette that doesn’t simply feed the community; it engages it as well. The market sells produce, Asian pantry items, and dishes prepared by Sivrican’s mom and extended community. Click the link in our bio to read more about this little shop with a big heart. 📷: @yungbludlau

node.text: L.A. kalbi is a uniquely Korean-American dish, a variation on traditional kalbi that uses thin-cut flanken-style short ribs rather than the butterflied English-style ribs commonly used in Korea. This style of short rib soaks up marinade fast, takes no time to grill, and yields tender meat that’s sweet, salty, and well-caramelized all over. Usually marinated in a combination of soy sauce, toasted sesame oil, garlic, ginger, and a sweetener, this recipe from chef Irene Yoo (@yooeating) uses grated Asian pear and granulated sugar to add sweetness. While the meat can shine just fine on its own with a simple bowl of rice and some kimchi, Yoo’s recipe goes all-out with everything you need to enjoy the kalbi in ssam (lettuce wraps): fresh leaf lettuce and perilla leaves for wrapping; pa muchim, a fresh, lightly dressed scallion salad that cuts through the ribs’ meaty sweetness; and hot, cooked short-grain rice. You’ll be licking your fingers (and the bones) clean. Click the link in our bio to pull off this Korean barbecue feast at home. 📷: @isa.zapata 🍴: @rice.isnice

node.text: With the freshest fruits and veggies at our fingertips, we couldn’t think of a better moment to celebrate the season with quick, easy, produce-forward dishes. Spend these last few summer weekends sniffing out the ripest tomatoes and feeling for the perfect peach, because that means whatever you make with them will be *that* much better. So whether you're trying to figure out what to do with that giant pile of summer squash from your garden or looking for new grilling recipes to try, the list at the link in our bio has you covered. 📷: @emmafishman, @isa.zapata, @yudi_ela 🍴: @rice.isnice, @susietheodorou, @rebeccajurkevich 🥣: @tripleppp, @sophiestrangio

node.text: A tart-sweet, hot-pink hibiscus syrup is the star of this bright and refreshing cocktail. Bar professional Cari Hah’s (@carisunnie) quick recipe makes enough syrup for 16 drinks, making it great for a crowd. Have leftovers? There are endless creative ways to use it up. Drizzle some over ice cream, use it as a sweetener for lemonade or iced tea, or mix it into more gin- or tequila-based cocktails. Click the link in our bio and get ready for refreshment. Cheers! 📷: @emmafishman 🍴: @rice.isnice 🥣: @aeswist

node.text: Big news! The first episode of our new podcast Food People just dropped, and we can’t wait for you to listen. In this episode, we’re asking the most pressing food question of all time. Just kidding, we’re talking about chicken. Senior food editor @andybaraghani and assistant food editor @thelescook spent many hours testing grilled chicken recipes for the August issue, and today they join host @amandashaps to share everything they learned. Learn the pros and cons of dry rubs vs. marinades, what “zone grilling” really means, and why Andy always carves his poultry alone.  Plus alexandrabeggs graces us with a very special segment, “Cook, Marry, Grill.” Hit that link in bio to listen, rate, review, and subscribe wherever you get your podcasts. 🎨: @tesssmithroberts

Unlike cooking it in the oven we're grilling it on a direct surface. It just makes it easier to cook evenly if the surface area is opened up." JESSIE YUCHEN Bon Appétit Assistant Food Editor'.

And that's it. And then you just, uh, arrange it on a platter and call it a day. They don't need to see you break sweat, it's fine." ANDY BARAGHANI Bon Appétit Test Kitchen Veteran'.

node.text: You know fall is coming when all you want to cook is a stick-to-your-ribs braise. And in this recipe by associate food editor Rachel Gurjar (@rachegurjar), two ingredients make these braised short ribs really stand out: fresh coconut and curry leaves. Unlike dried coconut, the fresh stuff doesn’t need to be toasted to bring out its natural nutty and sweet flavors (though dried will work just fine here in a pinch). And the fresh curry leaves impart a subtle citrusy, nutty, lemongrass-like taste unlike anything else. Click the link in our bio to get your braise on. 📷: @emmafishman 🍴: @rebeccajurkevich 🥣: @sophiestrangio
